results.title: Fasciola
results.brief_description: The life history of a nematode (the liver fluke), showing in detail its structure and its habits. The habits of the snail are then examined and shown to be a source of danger of infection. A detailed study of the life-cycle of the liver-fluke, showing the egg and the first larvae, the intermediate host - a snail, the second larvae, and, finally, the encysted third larvae, which are a source of infection to sheep, cattle, horses, dogs, and humans. The film shows that the most effective methods od dealing with fluke is to eliminate the conditions which are favourable for the breeding of the intermediate host, the snails. A gap is thereby created in the life-cycle of the fluke, as it cannot reproduce without the snails to act as intermediate host to the first larvae.

results.title: Farrebique
results.creator_credit: Films Etienne Lallier, Ecran Francais and Georges Rouquier
results.brief_description: Farrebique is the first feature-length work for French documentary filmmaker Georges Rouqier. Filmed in 1944 and 45, the focus is on one year in the life of a rural French family, observing them through the seasons. The family, cousins of the director living in the farming community of Aveyron in South-central France, act out sequences that correspond to actual events unfurling in their lives. Ideas of modernisation are slowly introduced; the notion of installing electricity for example is debated heatedly among key family members whilst the manual labours of farming life are clearly displayed. A fine example of ‘cinema verite’, the cycle of the seasons is linked to the cycles of life — birth, death, renewal — providing a humanist view of nature and the intrinsic phases of rural life. Featuring beautiful time-lapse photography to display the coming of Spring, the film can be read as a paean to a bucolic life, observing the minutiae of nature as well as documenting the hardships of working the land. This fascinating work is highly regarded and won numerous awards including the FIPRESCI Prize at Cannes, 1946.

results.title: Farnborough looks forward (1957)
results.brief_description: A survey of the aeroplanes on exhibition at the 1957 Farnborough Air Show featuring some of the latest developments in British aircraft design. Missiles on display included the Thunderbird, Bloodhound, Sea Slug and Firestreak; new aircraft - the Fairy Delta 2 capable of reaching a speed of 1100 mph.

results.title: Farnborough International 1974
results.brief_description: The first International Farnborough Airshow. Europe’s top aerospace manufacturers announced that they had decided to work together for aircraft needs for the 1980s. The keynote was co-operation - from the Anglo-French Concorde and Jaguar to the European airbus.

results.title: Farnborough fly past (1955)
results.brief_description: The highlights of the 1955 Farnborough Air Show showing the latest developments in British civil and military aircraft. Aircraft appearing in the film include: the English Electric “P-1”, the first British aircraft to exceed the speed of sound in level flight; the Fairey “Delta II”, the Folland “Gnat I”, the new Hawker “Hunter F4”, the Fairey “Jet Gyrodyne” helicopter; and the de Havilland Gyron, claimed to be the most powerful type-tested engine yet announced.

results.title: Farnborough Air Show (1949)
results.brief_description: The Society of Aircraft Constructors’ Show at Farnborough, England, in 1949, is described in detail. The various types of new British aircraft are shown being put through their paces. Commentary by Leslie Mitchell.

results.title: Farnborough 1968
results.brief_description: Farnborough Air Show - 26th exhibition and flying display. Includes flight demonstrations and equipment and models on display. Aircraft includes Comet, Jetstream, BAC 1-11, Japanese Turbo Prop, Harrier Jet and many more.

results.title: Farnborough 1966
results.brief_description: The Farnborough Air Show features a large range of aircraft: airliners, executive craft, helicopters, military and private planes. For the first time European aircraft are also taking part, all powered by British engines. A great many missiles and aircraft components and accessories are on view, and there is a display of parachuting, gliding and aerobatics.

results.title: Farnborough 1960
results.brief_description: The 1960 annual show of the British aircraft industry, exhibiting the latest developments in aeronautical engineering and missiles. Among the main features were the Jindivik, a radio-controlled target plane, the hovercraft, the short sc.1 Vertical take-off research jet plane and among various new civil types, the Avro 748 airliner freighter. The flying display included team aerobatics by the famous “Black Arrows” Hunter jets of 111 squadron, R.A.F.

results.title: Farmyard stories = better move on frog ...
results.creator_credit: Gerben Cath and International Video Books
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Butler’s Video Books”.
A video designed to encourage children to read and enjoy books. Ten different stories, many from well known books, are told by professional storytellers in a farmyard setting and have been selected for children aged one to five years old. The stories are: “Mrs. Mopple’s washing line”, “Sophie and Jack”, “Better move on frog”, “Teddy at the seaside”, “Bookload of animals”, “Mr. Ginger’s potato”, “Wilberforce goes on a picnic”, “Ambo and the little elephant”, “Peter Pipers at the wildlife park”, “Hairy Mclary from Donaldson’s dairy” Introduced by Dorothy Butler.
